thread.title: SkinnyPop-maker Amplify’s stock drops on its debut
thread.title_full: SkinnyPop-maker Amplify’s stock drops on its debut - MarketWatch

author: By     Tomi Kilgore
title: SkinnyPop-maker Amplify’s stock drops on its debut
text:
SkinnyPop popcorn maker Amplify Snack Brands Inc.’s shares didn’t have a good first day in the stock market, but that didn’t seem to phase the salty-snack company’s chief executive.
The stock’s BETR, -1.18% first trade on the New York Stock Exchange was at 10:24 a.m. Eastern, at $17. That was 5.6% below the initial public offering price of $18 , which was above the expected pricing range of $14 to $16. The stock closed Wednesday at $16.14, or 10% below the IPO price, and near the bottom of the intraday trading range of $16.01 to $17.20.
Chief Executive Tom Ennis said the company is still in the early stages, but it has been showing strong growth within the burgeoning better-for-you (BFY) snack industry. Read more about Amplify’s sales growth .
“We’re building a great company, and we’ve been able to demonstrate great success,” Ennis said in an interview with MarketWatch. “We think the future is very bright.”
Part of Ennis’s plan for growth includes acquisitions, within the BFY salty-snack category they know, of course. But after acquiring Paqui Tortilla Chips in April, it could be another year before the company takes the plunge again.
“Our cadence for acquisitions is every 12 to 18 months,” Ennis said. “Nothing specific [at the moment], but we talk to a lot of folks.”
He said they look for smaller brands, that have very strong followings in their markets, just like Paqui.
By the way, Paqui, which means “happy” in Aztec, is pronounced “pocky.” But Ennis said it doesn’t bother him that many people pronounce it “packy.”
“We don’t really mind, as long as they eat it,” Ennis said.
Amplify didn’t raise money in the initial public offering to make acquisitions. In fact, all of the proceeds are going to selling stockholders — the company doesn’t get any of that money.
“We have a great balance sheet….We’re not over levered,” Ennis said. “We think we can do what we need to do with what we have today.”
